Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) with no known drug allergies. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.1°C (97°F), heart rate of 96 beats per minute (bpm), blood pressure of 91/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on a medium concentration mask.

The patient is receiving infusions and other ICU medications, including antibiotics, and has a 22-gauge central venous catheter inserted on [**2168-6-7**] at 06:51 AM. The patient's fluid balance is stable, with no fluid input or output noted.

The patient's cardiac rhythm is atrial fibrillation, and they are receiving prophylactic measures for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

The patient's physical examination is limited due to lack of assessment, and laboratory results are pending. The patient's code status is not specified, and their disposition is not mentioned.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on this information include:

1. Sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's underlying condition and receipt of antibiotics.
2. Thromboembolic events, such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis, despite prophylactic measures.
3. Respiratory failure or worsening respiratory distress due to the patient's atrial fibrillation and potential cardiac dysfunction.
4. Infection or pneumonia due to the patient's respiratory support and potential aspiration.
5. Metabolic complications, such as hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia, due to the patient's altered metabolic state and receipt of antibiotics.
6. Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to the patient's atrial fibrillation and potential cardiac dysfunction.
7. Neurological complications, such as stroke or encephalopathy, due to the patient's underlying condition and potential cardiac or respiratory dysfunction.

Chief Complaint: Transfer to CCU for hypotension
   24 Hour Events: : Mr. [**Known lastname 6286**] is a 79M w/ hx of critical AS (valve area
   0.5cm2), sCHF, alcoholic cirrhosis, DM, recently admitted w/ sCHF
   exacerbation and worsening of AS, who p/w persistent severe DOE  on
   [**2168-5-30**]. Please see admit note and team progress notes for more details.
   Briefly, DOE was evaluated by the team with TTE and was found to be
   likely due to critical AS with a valve area of 0.5 and gradient of 60.
   Plan was for patient to undergo aortic valvuloplasty today. Patient
   thought to be slightly overloaded due to othropnea so was given lasix
   20 mg IVx1. Patient put out 250 cc and was found on routine vitals
   check to have BP 81/52, temp 97.1, HR 103, RR 30, and 95% 4L. Patient
   triggered for hypotension as his SBP normally runs in the 110s.
   Patient as given 650 cc of NS. UA with positive Ntr, small LE, and 12
   wbc. CBC shows new leukocytosis. Started empirically on Vanco/Zosyn.
   Also of note patient has had guiac positive stools. Transferred to CCU
   for further management of critical AS.

   79M w/ hx of critical AS (valve area 0.5cm2), sCHF, alcoholic
   cirrhosis, DM, recently admitted w/ sCHF exacerbation and worsening of
   AS, who no p/w persistent severe DOE due to critical AS now awaiting
   valvuloplasty.
   # Critical AS: Recent echo showed valve area 0.5mm2, pt's current
   symptoms of severe DOE due to AS. Awaiting valvulplasty later on today.
   [**Month (only) 8**] have been overdiuresed yesterday leading to poor forward flow and
   subsequent hypotension. Although patient only put out 300 cc to lasix,
   patient did have profuse diarrhea which may have also led to volume
   shifts. BP has responded to small fluid bolus of 650 cc on the floor.
   -  Plan to hold off on further fluids. Goal MAP greater than 55.
   Peripheral dopamine if needed. Will hold on further fluids for now.
   - Plan for Valvuloplasty today
   # New onset A fib: Noted on admission. Cardioversion [**6-3**]. Chads 2 is

   Appears in a fib right now on tele, but rate controlled less than 100.
   -Hold heparin gtt
   -active t and s
   - 12 lead EKG now
   - Continue dofetelide
   # Sepsis: Given diarrhea, Cdiff in differential, even though C diff
   negative x1. UA points to possible urinary source. Patient had
   previously reported a cough but may have been due to over hydration.
   Patient does meet sepsis criteria with positive UA, in addition to low
   grade fever, leukocytosis, increase RR, and tachycardia. Waxing and
   [**Doctor Last Name 226**] MS may be delirium.
   - Start empiric Vanco/Zosyn
   - Follow culture data
   - Will need central access
   - repeat C diff
   # Acute renal failure: Likely due to poor forward flow in the setting
   of sepsis and critical AS.
   - Trend Cr. Renally dose meds
   - Urine lytes
   # Cirrhosis: - Likely [**2-29**] EtOH use. Pt reports that he stopped drinking
   approx 1 year ago.documented on MRCP as well as CT abdomen. Pt
   hepatitis panel negative for Hep A,B,C. G positive stools may be due to
   upper GIB but no report of [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 6297**] so unlikely variceal bleed.
   In addition EGD [**2168-6-2**] without varices. EGD did show Erythema and
   congestion in the first part of the duodenum, second part of the
   duodenum and third part of the duodenum compatible with mild
   duodenitis. Given brown stools, and Hct drop, in the setting of
   heparin, history is most consistent with likely upper source of GIB.
   -2 pivs
   -active T and S
   -Consider IV ppi
   - Consider reconsulting GI
   # DM
 ISS
   # FEN
 NPO
   # Access: PIV
   # PPx
 No heparin given ? GIB
   # Code- DNR/I

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis, severe congestive heart failure, alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes. He was admitted with exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS. He has been experiencing persistent severe dyspnea and was found to have a valve area of 0.5cm2 with a gradient of 60. He was given lasix 20mg IV, which resulted in a 250cc output and a subsequent drop in blood pressure to 81/52mmHg. He was given 650cc of NS and was found to have a positive UA with small LE and 12 wbc. He was started on empiric Vanco/Zosyn and has been transferred to the CCU for further management.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient's condition is critical, and valvuloplasty is planned today. However, there is a risk of further decompensation, including hypotension, cardiogenic shock, and cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient has met sepsis criteria with positive UA, low-grade fever, leukocytosis, increased RR, and tachycardia. There is a risk of further deterioration, including organ dysfunction and death.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine is likely to rise due to poor forward flow, sepsis, and critical AS. There is a risk of further deterioration, including need for dialysis.
4. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has guaiac-positive stools and a history of EGD showing erythema and congestion in the duodenum, which is compatible with mild duodenitis. There is a risk of further bleeding, including variceal bleeding.
5. Hepatic Encephalopathy: The patient has cirrhosis and a history of EtOH use. There is a risk of further deterioration, including encephalopathy and hepatic failure.
6. Cardiac Arrhythmias: The patient has atrial fibrillation and is at risk of further arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia and fibrillation.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is at risk of further deterioration, including respiratory failure.
8. Infection: The patient has a positive UA and is at risk of further infection, including bacteremia and septicemia.

These potential medical complications require close monitoring and management by the ICU team to prevent further deterioration and improve the patient's outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe chronic heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS, leading to persistent severe dyspnea on exertion (DOE). The patient was treated with lasix 20 mg IV, which resulted in hypotension. He was given 650 cc of normal saline and was transferred to the CCU for further management.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: BP 91/53 mmHg, HR 96 bpm, RR 21 breaths/min, SpO2 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: MAP 55 mmHg
* Fluid balance: 650 cc of normal saline given, urine output 0 mL
* Respiratory support: oxygen delivery device, SpO2 100%
* Physical examination: ill appearing, somnolent, tachypneic, irregular heart rhythm
* Labs/Radiology: UA positive for nitrite, small LE, and 12 wbc; CBC shows new leukocytosis; abdominal CT scan shows cirrhosis
* Assessment and plan:
	+ Critical AS: awaiting valvuloplasty later today
	+ New onset atrial fibrillation (AF): rate controlled, holding heparin gtt, and continuing dofetilide
	+ Leukocytosis: empiric treatment with Vanco/Zosyn, considering C. difficile in differential
	+ sCHF: holding off on further fluids, goal MAP greater than 55, and considering peripheral dopamine
	+ Hyponatremia: fluid restriction to 1.5 L/day
	+ Cirrhosis: liver consult in the morning
	+ DM2: continuing glipizide and starting ISS
	+ HTN: not on any hypertensives, considering liver consult for operative risk

Potential medical complications:

* Volume overload: the patient has been overdiuresed, leading to hypotension, and may develop volume overload if further fluids are given.
* C. difficile colitis: the patient's diarrhea and leukocytosis may indicate C. difficile infection, which needs to be treated promptly.
* Sepsis: the patient's positive UA, leukocytosis, and low-grade fever may indicate sepsis, which needs to be monitored and treated aggressively.
* Liver failure: the patient's cirrhosis may lead to liver failure, which needs to be monitored and managed carefully.
* Cardiac complications: the patient's critical AS and new onset AF may lead to cardiac complications, such as heart failure, cardiogenic shock, or arrhythmias.
* Respiratory complications: the patient's tachypnea and hypoxia may lead to respiratory complications, such as respiratory failure or pneumonia.

Summary:

The patient, a 79-year-old male, was transferred to the CCU for hypotension. He has a history of critical aortic stenosis (valve area 0.5cm2), systolic heart failure, alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with an exacerbation of systolic heart failure and worsening aortic stenosis. The patient was found to have a likely critical aortic stenosis with a valve area of 0.5cm2 and a gradient of 60. He was given Lasix 20mg IV, which resulted in a 250cc fluid output, but his blood pressure dropped to 81/52mmHg. He was also found to have a positive urine analysis with a small amount of leukocytes, a new leukocytosis, and guaiac-positive stools.

The patient's current vital signs are: temperature 97.1°C, heart rate 103bpm, respiratory rate 30insp/min, and oxygen saturation 100% on a medium concentration mask. His physical examination reveals an irregular heart rhythm, tachycardia, and a harsh late-peaking semisternal murmur. He has a positive bowel sound, soft abdomen, and palpable peripheral pulses.

The patient's lab results show a new leukocytosis, and he has been started on empiric antibiotics. He has also been given a liver consult to determine his operative risk with a history of cirrhosis. The patient's cardiac catheterization is planned for the morning to further evaluate the stenosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening of aortic stenosis: The patient's critical aortic stenosis may worsen if not treated promptly, leading to further symptoms of severe dyspnea and heart failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's positive urine analysis and new leukocytosis may indicate an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis if not treated promptly.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's history of cirrhosis and recent liver function tests may indicate a risk of hepatic encephalopathy, which could lead to altered mental status and increased risk of complications.
4. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's new atrial fibrillation may worsen if not treated promptly, leading to further cardiac complications.
5. Pulmonary edema: The patient's euvolemia and recent fluid output may indicate a risk of pulmonary edema, which could worsen his respiratory symptoms.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's guaiac-positive stools may indicate a risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which could worsen his anemia and increase his risk of complications.
7. Infection: The patient's recent antibiotic use and positive urine analysis may indicate a risk of infection, which could lead to further complications if not treated promptly.
8. Renal dysfunction: The patient's history of diabetes and recent fluid output may indicate a risk of renal dysfunction, which could worsen his overall condition.

Based on the patient's current condition and potential medical complications, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status. Prompt treatment of his critical aortic stenosis, sepsis, and other potential complications is crucial to improve his outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis, severe chronic heart failure, and alcoholic cirrhosis, who was recently admitted for an exacerbation of chronic heart failure and worsening aortic stenosis. He presented with persistent severe dyspnea and was found to have a critical aortic valve area of 0.5 cm² and a gradient of 60 mmHg. The patient underwent aortic valvuloplasty, but developed hypotension and was transferred to the Cardiac Care Unit (CCU) for further management. He received lasix 20 mg IV and was given 650 cc of normal saline. The patient was also started on empiric antibiotics and has guaiac-positive stools.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Cardiogenic shock due to critical aortic stenosis
	* Heart failure exacerbation
	* Arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation, may worsen
2. Respiratory Complications:
	* Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to fluid overload
	* Pneumonia or aspiration pneumonia due to impaired cough and swallowing
3. Gastrointestinal Complications:
	* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to cirrhosis and potential bleeding diathesis
	* Intestinal ischemia or infarction due to hypoperfusion
4. Infection Complications:
	* Sepsis due to bacteremia or pneumonia
	* Endocarditis due to cardiac catheterization or valvuloplasty
5. Other Complications:
	* Renal failure due to hypotension and fluid overload
	* Liver failure due to worsening cirrhosis
	* Anemia or bleeding due to guaiac-positive stools

TEXT:
Chief Complaint: Transfer to CCU for hypotension
   24 Hour Events: : Mr. [**Known lastname 6286**] is a 79M w/ hx of critical AS (valve area
   0.5cm2), sCHF, alcoholic cirrhosis, DM, recently admitted w/ sCHF
   exacerbation and worsening of AS, who p/w persistent severe DOE  on
   [**2168-5-30**]. Please see admit note and team progress notes for more details.
   Briefly, DOE was evaluated by the team with TTE and was found to be
   likely due to critical AS with a valve area of 0.5 and gradient of 60.
   Plan was for patient to undergo aortic valvuloplasty today. Patient
   thought to be slightly overloaded due to othropnea so was given lasix
   20 mg IVx1. Patient put out 250 cc and was found on routine vitals
   check to have BP 81/52, temp 97.1, HR 103, RR 30, and 95% 4L. Patient
   triggered for hypotension as his SBP normally runs in the 110s.
   Patient as given 650 cc of NS. UA with positive Ntr, small LE, and 12
   wbc. CBC shows new leukocytosis. Started empirically on Vanco/Zosyn.
   Also of note patient has had guiac positive stools. Transferred to CCU
   for further management of critical AS.

   Physical Examination
   Gen: ill appearing, somnolent, tachypneic, originally A and OX1 but now
   A and OX3
   HEENT: no appreciable JVD while lying flat (for hypotension)
   CV: Irregular, tachycardic, [**4-1**] harsh late peaking SEM, no rubs or
   gallops
   Pulm: CTA
   Abdomen: +BS, soft, NT, ND, no organomealy
   Exts: WWP, no c/c/e, thready DP and PT pulses but palpable
   Labs / Radiology
        [image002.jpg]
   Assessment and Plan:
   79M w/ hx of critical AS (valve area 0.5cm2), sCHF, alcoholic
   cirrhosis, DM, recently admitted w/ sCHF exacerbation and worsening of
   AS, who no p/w persistent severe DOE due to critical AS now awaiting
   valvuloplasty.
   # Critical AS: Recent echo showed valve area 0.5mm2, pt's current
   symptoms of severe DOE due to AS. Awaiting valvulplasty later on today.
   [**Month (only) 8**] have been overdiuresed yesterday leading to poor forward flow and
   subsequent hypotension. Although patient only put out 300 cc to lasix,
   patient did have profuse diarrhea which may have also led to volume
   shifts. BP has responded to small fluid bolus of 650 cc on the floor.
   -  Plan to hold off on further fluids. Goal MAP greater than 55.
   Peripheral dopamine if needed. Will hold on further fluids for now.
   - Plan for Valvuloplasty today
   # New onset A fib: Noted on admission. Prior cardioversion [**6-3**]. Chads
   2 is 4. Was on heparin gtt on the floor but will d/c now given hct
   drop. Appears in a fib right now on tele, but rate controlled less than
   100.
   -Hold heparin gtt
   -active t and s
   - 12 lead EKG now
   - Continue dofetelide
   # Sepsis: Given diarrhea, Cdiff in differential. UA points to possible
   urinary source. Patient had previously reported a cough but may have
   been due to over hydration. Patient does meet sepsis criteria with
   positive UA, in addition to low grade fever, leukocytosis, increase RR,
   and tachycardia. Waxing and [**Doctor Last Name 226**] MS may be delirium.
   - Start empiric Vanco/Zosyn
   - Follow culture data
   - Will need central access
   - C diff
   # Acute renal failure: Likely due to poor forward flow in the setting
   of sepsis and critical AS.
   - Trend Cr. Renally dose meds
   - Urine lytes
   # Cirrhosis: - First noted during ccy, Likely [**2-29**] EtOH use. Pt reports
   that he stopped drinking approx 1 year ago.documented on MRCP as well
   as CT abdomen. Pt hepatitis panel negative for Hep A,B,C. Pt had liver
   f/u as outpt for possible endoscopy and pre-op Child's classification
   and bleeding risk. Pt did have thombocytopenia and elevated INR on last
   admission (peaked plt 106, and INR 1.6), and started on Vit. K.
   Currently Albumin 3.4, Cr, Tbili normal. G positive stools may be due
   to upper GIB but no report of [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 6297**] so unlikely variceal
   bleed.
   # DM
 ISS
   # FEN
 NPO
   # Access: PIV
   # PPx
 None right now
   # Code- DNR/I
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   22 Gauge - [**2168-6-7**] 06:51 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (valve area 0.5cm2), severe chronic heart failure, alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes. He was recently admitted with a severe exacerbation of chronic heart failure and worsening aortic stenosis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 97.1°C, heart rate 103 beats per minute, blood pressure 91/53 mmHg, respiratory rate 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 100%.
* Physical examination: The patient is ill appearing, somnolent, tachypneic, and has a harsh late-peaking systolic murmur.
* Laboratory results: The patient has a white blood cell count of 12,000 cells per microliter, with a positive urine culture and a positive stool test for guaiac.
* ECG: The patient is in atrial fibrillation with a rate of less than 100 beats per minute.

The patient's condition is complex and potentially life-threatening. The potential medical complications that can arise from his condition include:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's critical aortic stenosis and atrial fibrillation can lead to cardiac arrest, heart failure, and arrhythmias.
2. Sepsis: The patient's positive urine culture and stool test for guaiac suggest the possibility of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's decreased urine output and elevated creatinine level suggest the possibility of acute renal failure, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances and acidosis.
4. Cirrhosis: The patient's history of alcoholic cirrhosis and elevated liver enzymes suggest the possibility of liver failure, which can lead to coagulopathy, ascites, and encephalopathy.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's positive stool test for guaiac and history of gastrointestinal bleeding suggest the possibility of gastrointestinal complications, such as upper gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.

In summary, the patient is a high-risk individual with multiple medical complications who requires close monitoring and management to prevent further deterioration of his condition.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS. The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Critical AS with a valve area of 0.5 cm2 and a gradient of 60.
2. Hypotension (BP 81/52 mmHg) with a normal blood pressure of 110s.
3. New onset atrial fibrillation (AF) with a rate-controlled less than 100.
4. Sepsis with a positive urine culture, leukocytosis, and tachycardia.
5. Acute renal failure (ARF) likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS.
6. Cirrhosis with a history of ethanol use and gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB).
7. Diarrhea and profuse stool loss, which may have contributed to volume shifts and hypotension.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Awaiting valvuloplasty today.
2. Holding off on further fluids to achieve a goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 55.
3. Starting empiric antibiotic therapy with Vanco/Zosyn.
4. Monitoring for sepsis and adjusting treatment as necessary.
5. Trending creatinine levels and adjusting medication dosages accordingly.
6. Considering IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and reconsulting gastroenterology for further management of GIB.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Worsening of hypotension and decreased cardiac output.
2. Progression of sepsis and ARF.
3. Development of cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
4. Increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and perforation.
5. Need for further interventions, such as central access or repeat C difficile testing.
6. Potential for delirium and cognitive impairment due to sepsis and critical illness.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be determined:

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old man with a history of critical aortic stenosis, severe congestive heart failure, alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS. The patient experienced hypotension, likely due to overdiuresis and volume shifts, and was transferred to the CCU for further management. He has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, sepsis, acute renal failure, and likely upper gastrointestinal bleeding.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's diagnosis of sepsis is concerning, and if left untreated, it can lead to organ failure, septic shock, and death.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's acute renal failure is likely due to poor forward flow, sepsis, and critical AS. If not managed promptly, it can lead to chronic kidney disease, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of infections.
3. Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's diagnosis of upper GIB is concerning, and if not managed promptly, it can lead to hemorrhagic shock, electrolyte imbalances, and increased risk of infections.
4. Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient's critical AS is a life-threatening condition that requires prompt management. If left untreated, it can lead to heart failure, arrhythmias, and death.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is a concern, and if left untreated, it can lead to stroke, heart failure, and increased risk of mortality.

Based on the patient's progress note, it is essential to closely monitor his condition and manage his medical complications promptly to prevent further deterioration.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe chronic heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS, awaiting valvuloplasty.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Critical AS: Recent echocardiogram (TTE) showed valve area of 0.5 cm², and the patient's current symptoms of severe dyspnea on exertion (DOE) due to AS. Valvuloplasty is planned for today.
2. New-onset atrial fibrillation (A-fib): Noted on admission, and cardioversion is planned. The patient is currently rate-controlled, and heparin infusion has been discontinued due to a drop in hematocrit (Hct).
3. Sepsis: The patient meets sepsis criteria with positive urine analysis (UA), low-grade fever, leukocytosis, increased respiratory rate, and tachycardia. The differential diagnosis includes urinary tract infection (UTI) and Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) infection.
4. Acute renal failure (ARF): Likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of ethanol use, but he reports stopping drinking approximately one year ago. The liver function tests (LFTs) are normal, and the patient has no report of variceal bleed.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB): The patient has brown stools, and Hct drop, which is most consistent with an upper source of GIB.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's history of cirrhosis and potential upper GIB.
2. Worsening of heart failure due to the patient's critical AS and ARF.
3. Development of septic shock due to the patient's sepsis and potential UTI.
4. Progression of cirrhosis and potential development of liver failure.
5. Delayed or unsuccessful valvuloplasty due to the patient's critical condition.

In summary, the patient is a high-risk individual with multiple comorbidities, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent potential complications and improve his clinical outcomes.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Critical Aortic Stenosis (AS): The patient's AS is critical, and the valve area is less than 0.8 cm2. This condition can lead to heart failure, angina, and even sudden cardiac death.
2. Sepsis: The patient has bacteremia with Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, which can cause sepsis, organ failure, and mortality.
3. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's creatinine level has increased to 1.8 mg/dL, likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS.
4. Cirrhosis: The patient has a history of cirrhosis, which can lead to portal hypertension, ascites, and variceal bleeding.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding (GIB): The patient has a history of upper GIB, which can lead to anemia, hypovolemic shock, and mortality.
6. Upper Gastrointestinal Disease (UGID): The patient has mild duodenitis, which can lead to abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
7. Cardiac Arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which can lead to cardiac arrest, stroke, and mortality.
8. Endocarditis: The patient has bacteremia, which can lead to endocarditis, especially in the setting of critical AS.
9. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is 86 K/uL, which can lead to bleeding complications.
10. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient has an imbalance of electrolytes, including potassium, magnesium, and phosphorus, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

1. Continue phenylephrine to maintain MAPs greater than 55.
2. CXR to assess volume status.
3. Valvuloplasty later this week.
4. Continue Vancomycin with once-daily dosing.
5. Follow culture data.
6. Trend creatinine levels.
7. Renally dose medications.
8. Urine lytes.
9. Consider IV PPI.
10. Consider reconsulting GI.

The patient's family has been informed of the patient's condition, and the patient's code status is DNR/DNI.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (CHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening AS, awaiting valvuloplasty. The patient developed sepsis, with positive blood cultures for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus and urine cultures for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus. He also has acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL. The patient's volume status is tenuous, and he is retaining fluid, which is being managed with phenylephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 55 mmHg. He has also developed atrial fibrillation and is being treated with dofetilide.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient's positive blood cultures for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus and the presence of bacteremia increase the risk of endocarditis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is being managed with antibiotics, but the risk of septic shock and multi-organ failure remains.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL indicates acute renal failure, which may progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed properly.
4. Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient's critical AS increases the risk of cardiac complications, including heart failure, arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis increases the risk of complications, including bleeding, ascites, and encephalopathy.
6. Upper Gastrointestinal Bleeding (UGIB): The patient's history of upper GIB and the presence of erythema and congestion in the duodenum suggest a high risk of recurrent bleeding.
7. DVT: The patient's immobilization and presence of central venous catheters increase the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
8. Stress Ulcer: The patient's critical illness and use of corticosteroids increase the risk of stress ulcer bleeding.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics for sepsis and endocarditis.
2. Monitor the patient's creatinine level and adjust fluid management accordingly.
3. Consider referral to a cardiologist for further management of critical AS.
4. Monitor the patient's cirrhosis and manage potential complications, such as bleeding and ascites.
5. Continue to manage the patient's upper GIB with proton pump inhibitors and monitor for signs of bleeding.
6. Consider prophylactic anticoagulation to reduce the risk of DVT.
7. Monitor the patient's stress ulcer risk and consider prophylactic treatment with histamine-2 (H2) blockers or proton pump inhibitors.

   -Cordis placed. Pt started on Dopamine for SBP in high 60's; shortly
   thereafter, became tachy to 140's RR high 30's, SBP 70's. Dobutamine
   was stopped. Phenyl. started. Bolused 500cc's NS, then 250cc's, then
   100 cc's. CVP = 14. Tachychardia and Tachypnea improved, SBP 90's. CXR
   obtained = no pneumothorax. Repeat HCT not suggestive of bleeding.
   Patient much improved by 1800 hours.
   -Discussed case in full with HCP.
   -Holding on A line.
   -Gave 20mEq K (pm k = 3.7)
   -Vanc, Zosyn ID appropved.
   -2/4 bottles (both anaerobic), positive for GPC P and Cl's. Diff w 90.6
   P, 4.6 L.
   -Low suspicion for c. diff so not getting second set. Stopped Flagyl.
   - PPI ordered
   -TTE: Anterior septal akinesis. Pulm regurg. Aortic valve area under
   .8cm. LVH. NO THROMBI
   -ECHO w/o vegetations

   Assessment and Plan
   79M w/ hx of critical AS (valve area 0.5cm2), sCHF (EF 40), alcoholic
   cirrhosis, DM, recently admitted w/ sCHF exacerbation and worsening of
   AS, who no p/w persistent severe DOE due to critical AS now awaiting
   valvuloplasty, course complicated by sepsis.
   # Critical AS: AS critical by valve area and awaiting palliative
   valvuloplasy while Bacteremia clears. Volume status remains tenuous,
   and patient appears to be retaining. Limiting fluid intake as much as
   possible and utilizing phenylephrine to keep MAPs greater than 55
   because Dopa was complicated by tachycardia.
   -  Continue phenylephrine for MAPs greater than 55
   -  CXR to assess volume status
   -  Valvuloplasty later this week
   # New onset A fib: Noted on admission. Cardioversion [**6-3**]. Chads 2 is
   4. Was on heparin gtt on the floor but will d/c now given hct drop.
   Appears to be in NSR this am. Not on anticoagulation
   -Continue Dofetelide but plan to reduse dose and hold today given
   change in renal function
   - Plan to hold anticoagulation for possible procedure today or tomorrow
   (see above)
   # Sepsis: Urine culture growing coag. Neg staph and Blood cultures
   growing coag. Positive staph. No peripheral manifestations of
   endocarditis, and TTE negative for vegetations. No obvious sources for
   staph bacteremia. Sensitivities pending. C diff negative x1.
   - Continue Vancomycin but change to Once daily dosing. D/c Zosyn.
   - Check vanco level
   - Follow culture data
   - repeat C diff
   # Acute renal failure: Cr up to 1.8 from 1.6 yesterday. Likely due to
   poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS. Fena 0.2.
   - Trend Cr. Renally dose meds
   - goal 250 cc + today
   # Cirrhosis: - Likely [**2-29**] EtOH use. Pt reports that he stopped drinking
   approx 1 year ago.documented on MRCP as well as CT abdomen. Pt
   hepatitis panel negative for Hep A,B,C. G positive stools may be due to
   upper GIB but no report of [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 6297**] so unlikely variceal bleed.
   In addition EGD [**2168-6-2**] without varices. EGD did show Erythema and
   congestion in the first part of the duodenum, second part of the
   duodenum and third part of the duodenum compatible with mild
   duodenitis. Given brown stools, and Hct drop, in the setting of
   heparin, history is most consistent with likely upper source of GIB.
   Hct stable. LFTs increased likely due to shock liver.
   -2 pivs
   -active T and S
   -Change to po PPI
   # ?Aspiration: [**Name8 (MD) **] RN and patient report, patient coughs with thin
   liquids. Will defer swallow eval while NPO.
   - S and S consult tomorrow if tolerating diet
   # DM

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old man with a history of critical aortic stenosis, severe congestive heart failure, alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes. He was admitted with sepsis, bacteremia, and acute renal failure. The patient's condition has improved over the past 24 hours, with resolution of tachycardia and tachypnea after treatment with phenylephrine and bolus fluids.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis and bacteremia: The patient's blood cultures are positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and he has a high risk of developing septic shock and endocarditis.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level has increased to 1.8 mg/dL, and he is at risk of developing further kidney damage.
3. Critical aortic stenosis: The patient's valve area is less than 0.5 cm², and he is awaiting valvuloplasty. He is at risk of developing further cardiac complications, such as heart failure and arrhythmias.
4. Cirrhosis: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and he is at risk of developing further liver damage and complications.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, and he is at risk of developing further bleeding episodes.
6. Aspiration: The patient has a history of coughing with thin liquids, and he is at risk of developing aspiration pneumonia.
7. Ventricular arrhythmias: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, and he is at risk of developing ventricular arrhythmias.
8. Endocarditis: The patient's blood cultures are positive for coagulase-negative Staphylococcus, and he is at risk of developing endocarditis.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continue antibiotics for sepsis and bacteremia.
2. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and cardiac output closely.
3. Continue diuretics to manage fluid overload.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust medications as necessary.
5. Plan for valvuloplasty later this week.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust medications as necessary.
7. Consider endoscopy to evaluate the patient's upper gastrointestinal tract.
8. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and consider intubation if necessary.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient, a 79-year-old male, is admitted to the ICU with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (CHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis. He is awaiting valvuloplasty today. The patient's current symptoms include severe dyspnea due to AS, which has been exacerbated by his recent hospitalization.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.5°C (97.7°F)
* Heart rate: 83 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 93/55 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 23 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 93%

The patient's physical examination reveals:

* General appearance: ill appearing, lethargic but easily arousable
* Cardiovascular: regular rhythm, harsh late peaking S1, no rubs or gallops
* Pulmonary: crackles in the right base
* Abdomen: soft, non-tender, no organomegaly
* Extremities: 1+ edema 3 cm above ankle bilaterally, thready DP and PT pulses

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 13.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin: 13.8 g/dL
* Platelet count: 86 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Glucose: 101 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: normal
* Lactic acid: 2.2 mmol/L
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.9 mg/dL

The patient's conditions that require attention are:

1. Sepsis: The patient meets sepsis criteria with a positive urine analysis, low-grade fever, leukocytosis, increased respiratory rate, and tachycardia. The patient has been started on empiric Vancomycin and Zosyn, and central access will be needed.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS.
3. Cirrhosis: The patient's history of cirrhosis is likely due to ethanol use, and he has reported stopping drinking approximately one year ago. The patient's gastrointestinal symptoms may be due to upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB), and he has been prescribed proton pump inhibitors and is being considered for reconsultation with gastroenterology.
4. Critical aortic stenosis: The patient's valve area is 0.5 cm², and he is awaiting valvuloplasty today.
5. New-onset atrial fibrillation: The patient has been cardioverted and is currently in atrial fibrillation with a controlled rate.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of sepsis and acute renal failure
* Progression of critical aortic stenosis
* Development of further gastrointestinal bleeding
* Increased risk of bleeding due to anticoagulation therapy
* Increased risk of arrhythmias due to atrial fibrillation

I recommend close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status to address these conditions and potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe chronic heart failure (sCHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis, who was recently admitted with sCHF exacerbation and worsening of AS. He is awaiting valvuloplasty and is currently experiencing sepsis with bacteremia. The patient has developed acute renal failure, and his creatinine level has increased to 1.8 mg/dL. He also has mild duodenitis and is suspected to have upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). The patient is being managed with phenylephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 55 mmHg and is receiving antibiotics, including vancomycin and Zosyn.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Endocarditis: Given the presence of bacteremia and the patient's history of critical AS, there is a risk of developing endocarditis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to worsen if not properly managed, leading to further organ dysfunction and increased mortality.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's creatinine level has increased to 1.8 mg/dL, indicating AKI. This may further exacerbate his heart failure and increase his risk of mortality.
4. Gastrointestinal Hemorrhage: The patient's suspected upper GIB may worsen if not managed promptly, leading to hypovolemic shock and increased mortality.
5. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status may deteriorate if not properly managed, leading to respiratory failure and increased mortality.
6. Cardiac Arrest: The patient's history of critical AS and sCHF increases his risk of cardiac arrest, which may be precipitated by further deterioration in his cardiac function or the development of arrhythmias.
7. Infection: The patient's bacteremia and suspected GIB increase his risk of developing further infections, which may worsen his clinical status and increase his risk of mortality.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation, dysphagia, acute renal failure, aortic stenosis, bacteremia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. The patient's condition has improved significantly over the past 24 hours, with a decrease in tachycardia and tachypnea after the administration of phenylephrine and the cessation of dobutamine. The patient's blood pressure has stabilized, and their cardiac rhythm has converted to sinus rhythm. The patient's laboratory results show evidence of acute kidney injury, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications: The patient's aortic stenosis and bacteremia increase their risk of cardiac complications, such as cardiac tamponade, cardiogenic shock, or arrhythmias.
2. Respiratory Complications: The patient's acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and bacteremia increase their risk of respiratory complications, such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
3. Renal Complications: The patient's acute kidney injury (AKI) increases their risk of chronic kidney disease (CKD), end-stage renal disease (ESRD), or the need for dialysis.
4. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's anemia and bacteremia increase their risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, diarrhea, or constipation.
5. Infection Complications: The patient's bacteremia and increased risk of VAP increase their risk of sepsis, septic shock, or multi-organ failure.
6. Hemorrhagic Complications: The patient's anemia and thrombocytopenia increase their risk of bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding, intracranial hemorrhage, or retroperitoneal hemorrhage.
7. Neurological Complications: The patient's anemia and bacteremia increase their risk of neurological complications, such as seizures, encephalopathy, or stroke.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or mitigate these potential complications.

   79M w/ hx of critical AS (valve area 0.5cm2), sCHF, alcoholic
   cirrhosis, DM, recently admitted w/ sCHF exacerbation and worsening of
   AS, who no p/w persistent severe DOE due to critical AS now awaiting
   valvuloplasty.
   # Critical AS: Recent echo showed valve area 0.5mm2, pt's current
   symptoms of severe DOE due to AS. Awaiting valvulplasty later on today.
   [**Month (only) 8**] have been overdiuresed yesterday leading to poor forward flow and
   subsequent hypotension. Although patient only put out 300 cc to lasix,
   patient did have profuse diarrhea which may have also led to volume
   shifts. BP has responded to small fluid bolus of 650 cc on the floor.
   -  Plan to hold off on further fluids. Goal MAP greater than 55.
   Peripheral dopamine if needed. Will hold on further fluids for now.
   - Plan for Valvuloplasty today
   # New onset A fib: Noted on admission. Cardioversion [**6-3**]. Chads 2 is
   4. Was on heparin gtt on the floor but will d/c now given hct drop.
   Appears in a fib right now on tele, but rate controlled less than 100.
   -Hold heparin gtt
   -active t and s
   - 12 lead EKG now
   - Continue dofetelide
   # Sepsis: Given diarrhea, Cdiff in differential, even though C diff
   negative x1. UA points to possible urinary source. Patient had
   previously reported a cough but may have been due to over hydration.
   Patient does meet sepsis criteria with positive UA, in addition to low
   grade fever, leukocytosis, increase RR, and tachycardia. Waxing and
   [**Doctor Last Name 226**] MS may be delirium.
   - Start empiric Vanco/Zosyn
   - Follow culture data
   - Will need central access
   - repeat C diff
   # Acute renal failure: Likely due to poor forward flow in the setting
   of sepsis and critical AS.
   - Trend Cr. Renally dose meds
   - Urine lytes
   # Cirrhosis: - Likely [**2-29**] EtOH use. Pt reports that he stopped drinking
   approx 1 year ago.documented on MRCP as well as CT abdomen. Pt
   hepatitis panel negative for Hep A,B,C. G positive stools may be due to
   upper GIB but no report of [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 6297**] so unlikely variceal bleed.
   In addition EGD [**2168-6-2**] without varices. EGD did show Erythema and
   congestion in the first part of the duodenum, second part of the
   duodenum and third part of the duodenum compatible with mild
   duodenitis. Given brown stools, and Hct drop, in the setting of
   heparin, history is most consistent with likely upper source of GIB.
   -2 pivs
   -active T and S
   -Consider IV ppi
   - Consider reconsulting GI
   # DM
 ISS
   # FEN
 NPO
   # Access: PIV
   # PPx
 No heparin given ? GIB

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), systolic heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus (DM). He was admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening AS, awaiting valvuloplasty.

The patient's 24-hour events include the placement of a cordis, which was followed by tachycardia and tachypnea, which improved with the administration of phenylephrine. The patient's cardiac status was assessed with a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE), which showed anterior septal akinesis, pulmonary regurgitation, and aortic valve area less than 0.8 cm.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count (WBC): 13.7 K/uL
* Hematocrit (Hct): 38.7%
* Platelet count (Plt): 86
* Creatinine (Cr): 1.5 mg/dL
* Glucose: 101 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.2 mmol/L
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.9 mg/dL

The patient's clinical condition is summarized as follows:

* Vital signs: T 36.5°C, HR 83 bpm, BP 93/55 mmHg, RR 23 inspirations per minute, SpO2 93%
* Cardiovascular: Irregular, tachycardic, harsh late peaking semisternal murmur, no rubs or gallops
* Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation
* Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, no organomegaly
* Extremities: Warm and well-perfused

The patient's diagnosis and plan are as follows:

* Critical AS: Awaiting valvuloplasty
* New-onset atrial fibrillation: Cardioversion attempted, heparin discontinued due to Hct drop
* Sepsis: Empiric treatment with vancomycin and Zosyn, repeat C. diff test
* Acute renal failure: Trend Cr, renally dose medications
* Cirrhosis: Likely EtOH use, upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) suspected
* DM: NPO, consider IV PPI

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of cardiac status, including cardiac arrest
* Development of septic shock
* Progression of acute renal failure to chronic kidney disease
* Increased risk of bleeding due to coagulopathy
* Complications of upper GIB, including variceal bleeding
* Increased risk of nosocomial infections due to immunosuppression

Given the patient's complex medical status, it is essential to continue close monitoring and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent potential complications and improve outcomes.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (CHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis, who was admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening AS. He has been overdiuresed, leading to poor forward flow and hypotension. The patient's current symptoms include severe dyspnea, tachycardia, and tachypnea. He has a new onset of atrial fibrillation and meets criteria for sepsis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's symptoms of tachycardia, tachypnea, and low-grade fever, along with a positive urine analysis, suggest sepsis. Empiric antibiotics (Vanco/Zosyn) have been started, and central access will be needed.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's low urine output and elevated creatinine levels suggest acute renal failure, likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS.
3. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB) and recent EGD findings of duodenitis and erythema suggest a possible upper source of GIB.
4. Variceal Bleed: Although the patient's EGD did not show varices, the history of EtOH use and documented liver disease make variceal bleeding a possibility.
5. Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient's critical AS will require valvuloplasty, and the patient will need to be closely monitored for signs of worsening heart failure and decreased cardiac output.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's new onset of atrial fibrillation will need to be managed with rate control and consideration of cardioversion.
7. Dehydration: The patient's history of overdiuresis and poor fluid intake may lead to dehydration, which will need to be closely monitored and managed.
8. Infection: The patient's sepsis and GIB make infection a potential complication, and the patient will need to be closely monitored for signs of worsening infection.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs, including blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation.
2. Closely monitor the patient's fluid status and urine output to prevent dehydration and acute renal failure.
3. Continue empiric antibiotics (Vanco/Zosyn) and follow culture data.
4. Consider IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI) for stress ulcer prophylaxis.
5. Consult with gastroenterology for further management of GIB.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function tests (LFTs) and consider reconsulting with gastroenterology if liver function worsens.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and consider echocardiography to assess the severity of AS.
8. Consider cardioversion for atrial fibrillation if the patient's symptoms worsen or if the rhythm becomes hemodynamically unstable.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), systolic congestive heart failure (sCHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was admitted with an exacerbation of sCHF and worsening of AS.

The patient's condition has improved over the past 24 hours, with tachycardia and tachypnea resolving after dopamine was stopped and phenylephrine was started. His blood pressure has stabilized, and his central venous pressure (CVP) is 14 mmHg.

The patient has a positive Gram's stain for GPC P and Cl's, which is concerning for sepsis. He has a low suspicion for Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection, and his urine analysis (UA) is suggestive of a urinary source of infection.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 13.7 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) of 13.8 g/dL, and platelet count (Plt) of 86 K/uL. His creatinine (Cr) level is 1.5 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 21 mEq/L.

The patient has been diagnosed with acute renal failure, likely due to poor forward flow in the setting of sepsis and critical AS. He has also been diagnosed with cirrhosis, likely due to ethanol use.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Holding off on further fluids to maintain a mean arterial pressure (MAP) greater than 55 mmHg.
2. Continuing empiric treatment with vancomycin and Zosyn for sepsis.
3. Trending his creatinine level and adjusting his medications accordingly.
4. Repeating his C. diff test.
5. Considering central access for further treatment.
6. Trending his liver function tests (LFTs) and adjusting his medications accordingly.
7. Considering IV proton pump inhibitor (PPI) for upper gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB).
8. Reconsulting with the gastroenterology (GI) team.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's condition is worsening, and he is at risk of developing septic shock.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is at risk of developing acute kidney injury.
3. Upper gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of cirrhosis and is at risk of developing upper GIB.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient has critical AS and is at risk of developing cardiac complications, such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
5. Delirium: The patient's mental status is concerning, and he may be at risk of developing delirium.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is low, and he may be at risk of developing thrombocytopenia.
7. Infection: The patient has a positive Gram's stain, and he may be at risk of developing a secondary infection.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (valve area 0.5cm2), severe congestive heart failure (EF 40), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was recently admitted with a worsening of his AS and exacerbation of CHF.

The patient's current condition is complicated by sepsis, which was caused by MSSA bacteremia. He is awaiting valvuloplasty and has been experiencing hypovolemic hyponatremia, likely due to poor oral intake. His renal function is improving, with a current creatinine level of 1.3 mg/dL.

The patient has also developed new-onset atrial fibrillation, which is being managed with dofetilide at a reduced dose. He has a history of cirrhosis and positive stool tests for Giardia, but his liver function tests are stable.

The patient's current medications include vancomycin, phenylephrine, pantoprazole, and lorazepam. He has been weaned off of heparin due to a drop in his hematocrit.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Worsening of his heart failure and cardiac output due to the critical AS.
2. Development of endocarditis or septic shock due to the MSSA bacteremia.
3. Further decline in his renal function due to inadequate perfusion.
4. Increased risk of bleeding due to the discontinuation of heparin.
5. Potential for aspiration due to his coughing with thin liquids.
6. Increased risk of stroke due to his atrial fibrillation.
7. Complications related to his cirrhosis and Giardia infection.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Valvuloplasty today to improve his systemic perfusion.
2. Weaning of phenylephrine as tolerated to reduce afterload.
3. Repeat surveillance cultures to monitor for any further sepsis.
4. Close monitoring of his renal function and fluid status.
5. Management of his atrial fibrillation with dofetilide at a reduced dose.
6. Consideration of anticoagulation therapy post-procedure.
7. Continued prophylaxis for stress ulcer and VAP.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is a critically ill individual with multiple comorbidities, including sepsis, atrial fibrillation, dysphagia, acute renal failure, aortic stenosis, bacteremia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia. The patient is currently in the ICU and is being treated with various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and vasopressors. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.5°C, heart rate of 75 bpm, and blood pressure of 108/60 mmHg. The patient's respiratory status is also stable, with an oxygen saturation of 98% on nasal cannula.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to progress if not adequately treated, leading to organ dysfunction and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's acute renal failure is likely to worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as electrolyte imbalances and acid-base disturbances.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely to persist or worsen if not managed with anticoagulation and rate control medications, leading to complications such as stroke or heart failure.
4. Bacteremia: The patient's bacteremia is likely to persist or worsen if not adequately treated with antibiotics, leading to complications such as sepsis, organ dysfunction, and death.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely to worsen if not managed with blood transfusions or other treatments, leading to complications such as fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia is likely to worsen if not managed with platelet transfusions or other treatments, leading to complications such as bleeding, bruising, and petechiae.
7. DVT: The patient is at high risk for developing DVT, particularly in the setting of immobility and central venous catheters. If not adequately managed with anticoagulation and compression stockings, DVT can lead to complications such as pulmonary embolism and deep vein thrombosis.
8. Stress Ulcer: The patient is at high risk for developing stress ulcers, particularly in the setting of critical illness and corticosteroid use. If not adequately managed with proton pump inhibitors and other medications, stress ulcers can lead to complications such as bleeding, perforation, and death.
9. VAP: The patient is at high risk for developing VAP, particularly in the setting of mechanical ventilation and central venous catheters. If not adequately managed with antibiotics and other treatments, VAP can lead to complications such as sepsis, organ dysfunction, and death.

In conclusion, the patient is at high risk for developing various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe chronic heart failure (CHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis. He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening of AS. The patient is currently awaiting valvuloplasty and is experiencing hyponatremia, acute renal failure, and sepsis. He has a history of anxiety and pain, and is currently NPO.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Complications: The patient's chronic heart failure and aortic stenosis may lead to respiratory complications, such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
2. Renal Complications: The patient's acute renal failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to electrolyte imbalances and further complications.
3. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis may worsen if not properly managed, leading to multi-organ failure and increased risk of mortality.
4. Thromboembolic Complications: The patient's critical AS and cirrhosis may increase the risk of thromboembolic complications, such as pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's cirrhosis and history of EtOH use may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as variceal bleeding or ascites.
6. Neurological Complications: The patient's history of anxiety and pain may increase the risk of neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke.
7. Infection: The patient's sepsis may lead to secondary infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
8. Cardiac Complications: The patient's critical AS and CHF may lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or mitigate these complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of critical aortic stenosis, severe chronic heart failure, and alcoholic cirrhosis. He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of chronic heart failure and worsening aortic stenosis. The patient has been complicated by sepsis, acute kidney injury, and hyponatremia. He is awaiting valvuloplasty today. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 75 beats per minute, blood pressure of 108/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 98%. His lab results show elevated lactate levels, and he is being managed with phenylephrine to maintain a mean arterial pressure above 55 mmHg.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient's critical aortic stenosis and severe chronic heart failure put him at risk for cardiac complications such as heart failure exacerbation, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's ongoing sepsis from MSSA bacteremia may lead to further organ dysfunction, including renal failure, respiratory failure, and hepatic failure.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's elevated creatinine levels and decreased urine output indicate ongoing acute kidney injury. Further decline in kidney function may lead to the need for renal replacement therapy.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hypovolemic hyponatremia may worsen if he continues to have poor oral intake and fluid losses.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's history of cirrhosis and upper gastrointestinal bleeding puts him at risk for further bleeding complications.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's ongoing respiratory failure may worsen if he develops further lung complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome.
7. Neurological complications: The patient's history of liver disease and potential upper gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to neurological complications such as encephalopathy or seizures.
8. Infection: The patient's ongoing sepsis and potential upper gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to further infections, including pneumonia or bloodstream infections.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis, severe chronic heart failure, and alcoholic cirrhosis. He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of chronic heart failure and worsening aortic stenosis. The patient's condition is complicated by sepsis, acute renal failure, hyponatremia, and possible gastrointestinal bleeding. He is awaiting valvuloplasty today.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is ongoing, and there is a risk of further deterioration or development of organ dysfunction.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is improving, but there is a risk of further deterioration or need for dialysis.
3. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely due to hypovolemic hyponatremia, and there is a risk of further worsening if fluid management is not optimal.
4. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, and there is a risk of further bleeding or perforation.
5. Aspiration: The patient's coughing with thin liquids is a concern for aspiration, and there is a risk of respiratory compromise if not managed properly.
6. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's critical aortic stenosis and severe chronic heart failure increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure exacerbation or cardiac arrest.
7. Infection: The patient's sepsis and gastrointestinal bleeding increase the risk of further infection, including bacteremia or endocarditis.
8. Hemodynamic Instability: The patient's sepsis and cardiovascular disease increase the risk of hemodynamic instability, including hypotension or hypertension.
9. Respiratory Compromise: The patient's chronic heart failure and sepsis increase the risk of respiratory compromise, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
10. Nutritional Deficiencies: The patient's gastrointestinal bleeding and sepsis increase the risk of nutritional deficiencies, including malnutrition or electrolyte imbalances.

Summary:

The patient is a 79-year-old man with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), severe congestive heart failure (CHF), alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes mellitus. He was recently admitted with an exacerbation of CHF and worsening AS, and is awaiting valvuloplasty. He has developed sepsis, acute renal failure, and is at risk for aspiration. He is being treated with vancomycin, doxycycline, and phenylephrine, and is being monitored closely for fluid status and renal function.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Aspiration: The patient has a history of coughing with thin liquids, and is at risk for aspiration. A swallow evaluation is deferred while he is NPO, but may be necessary if he is able to tolerate diet.
2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, and he is at risk for further decline in renal function. Renal dosing of medications and close monitoring of fluid status are necessary to prevent further deterioration.
3. Sepsis: The patient has developed sepsis, and is at risk for further complications such as organ failure and death. Close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory results, and treatment with antibiotics and supportive care are necessary to manage this condition.
4. Critical Aortic Stenosis: The patient's AS is critical, and he is at risk for further deterioration if not treated promptly. Valvuloplasty is scheduled for later this week, and close monitoring of his condition is necessary to ensure that he is stable enough for the procedure.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient has cirrhosis, and is at risk for further complications such as variceal bleeding, encephalopathy, and liver failure. Close monitoring of his liver function and treatment with medications to prevent bleeding and encephalopathy are necessary to manage this condition.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, and is at risk for further bleeding. Close monitoring of his stool output and treatment with medications to prevent bleeding are necessary to manage this condition.
7. Electrolyte Imbalance: The patient has an electrolyte imbalance, with hypovolemic hyponatremia. Close monitoring of his electrolyte levels and treatment with medications to correct the imbalance are necessary to manage this condition.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for further complications, and close monitoring and treatment are necessary to manage his condition and prevent further deterioration.

The patient is an 79-year-old male with a history of critical aortic stenosis, severe chronic heart failure, alcoholic cirrhosis, and diabetes. He was admitted with severe chronic heart failure exacerbation and worsening aortic stenosis. He has been complicated by sepsis, acute renal failure, and possible upper gastrointestinal bleeding. He is awaiting valvuloplasty and has been experiencing hypovolemic hyponatremia due to poor oral intake.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Volume overload: The patient's volume status is tenuous, and he is retaining fluids, which may lead to worsening heart failure and increased risk of respiratory and cardiac complications.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is at risk of further renal deterioration due to sepsis, critical aortic stenosis, and potential upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
3. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has brown stools and a history of upper gastrointestinal bleeding, which may worsen his condition and increase the risk of bleeding complications.
4. Infection: The patient has sepsis and bacteremia, which may lead to further complications such as endocarditis, septic shock, and organ failure.
5. Heart failure: The patient has severe chronic heart failure, and his condition may worsen due to volume overload, infection, and potential cardiac complications.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient has mild atelectasis and may be at risk of developing respiratory failure due to his underlying heart and lung disease.
7. Bleeding complications: The patient is at risk of bleeding complications due to his coagulopathy, sepsis, and potential upper gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he is at risk of developing chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease if his condition is not managed properly.
9. Cardiovascular complications: The patient has critical aortic stenosis, and his condition may worsen due to volume overload, infection, and potential cardiac complications.
10. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of seizure disorder and may be at risk of developing neurological complications such as seizures or encephalopathy due to his underlying medical condition and potential medication side effects.

Summary:

The patient is an 79-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of critical aortic stenosis (AS), systolic heart failure (CHF), and alcoholic cirrhosis. He developed MSSA bacteremia, which was treated with Nafcillin. The patient underwent aortic valvuloplasty and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to the right coronary artery (RCA) on [**2168-6-9**]. He also developed hyponatremia, acute renal failure, and new-onset atrial fibrillation (Afib). The patient is currently receiving various medications, including phenylephrine, dofetelide, and midazolam.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's MSSA bacteremia may lead to sepsis, which could worsen his condition and increase the risk of complications.
2. Endocarditis: Although the patient's surveillance cultures are negative, the risk of endocarditis persists, especially given the presence of bacteremia.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's Cr levels are improving, but the risk of acute renal failure remains, particularly if his blood pressure is not well-controlled.
4. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia may worsen if he continues to receive D5W instead of normal saline (NS).
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's new-onset Afib may increase his risk of stroke, and cardioversion may be necessary to restore sinus rhythm.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's cirrhosis and PPI use may increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, particularly if he develops varices.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and CHF may increase his risk of respiratory failure, especially if he develops pneumonia.
8. Cardiac Arrhythmias: The patient's underlying cardiac conditions, including AS and CHF, may increase his risk of cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
9. Infection: The patient's recent procedures and indwelling lines may increase his risk of infection, particularly if his immune system is compromised.
10. Thromboembolic Events: The patient's anticoagulation therapy may increase his risk of thromboembolic events, such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE).

   24 Hour Events:
   - Cultures reveal MSSA bacteremia. Changed from Vanco to Nafcillin.
   Surveillance cultures remain NGTd x 2 days
   - Dofetelide dose unchanged because of changing Cr. [**Month (only) 8**] need increased
   dose if Cr remains stable or improved.
   - I/o Goal even to positive 500 cc
   - Reversed Code status for procedure
   - Back pain/anxiety responded midazolam 0.5 x1
   - Remains Hyponatremic so meds changed to NS instead of D5w. Urine
   sodium less than 10 and Osm 634 indicating hyponatremia from low intake
   vs insensible losses.
   - 2 pm lytes - Na trending up at 127. Cr improved to 1.1 from 1.3.
   - Aortic Valvuloplasy performed with change in peak valve gradient of
   roughly 20 mmHg, BMS x2 placed in RCA. Loaded with plavix 300 mg x1.
   - Noted to be in Afib but rate controlled post-procedure
   - Sheath time [**2159**]. Post cath check 0200 unremarkable. Heparin
   post-procedure started at 2 am along with plavix 300 mg x1. Scant
   bleeding noted at cath site. Bruising marked to eval for interval
   change.
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies

Based on the patient's progress note, here is a summary of the information:

The patient underwent an aortic valvuloplasty and had a change in peak valve gradient of approximately 20 mmHg. They also had two BMS placed in the RCA and were loaded with Plavix 300 mg x1. The patient was in AFib but had a controlled heart rate post-procedure.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Hyponatremia (low sodium) with a sodium level of 127 mmol/L
* Anemia (hemoglobin 11.4 g/dL)
* Thrombocytopenia (platelet count 86 K/uL)
* Elevated lactate levels (2.2 mmol/L)
* Elevated LDH levels (292 IU/L)
* Elevated troponin-T levels (40 ng/mL)

The patient's vital signs show:

* Tachycardia (heart rate 99 bpm)
* Hypotension (blood pressure 103/56 mmHg)
* Tachypnea (respiratory rate 25 inspirations per minute)
* Oxygen saturation 98%

The patient's physical examination shows:

* No peripheral pulses assessed
* No skin assessment
* No neurologic assessment
* Responds to stimuli, but movement and tone not assessed

The patient's medical history includes:

* Aortic stenosis
* Bacteremia
* Anemia, acute, secondary to blood loss
* Thrombocytopenia, acute
* Chronic heart failure
* Sepsis without organ dysfunction

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Further cardiac complications due to the aortic valvuloplasty
* Increased risk of bleeding due to thrombocytopenia and bacteremia
* Worsening of hyponatremia, potentially leading to seizures or coma
* Development of acute kidney injury or acute renal failure due to hypovolemia and/or sepsis
* Increased risk of respiratory failure due to tachypnea and hypoxemia
* Potential for further cardiovascular instability due to tachycardia and hypotension
* Increased risk of sepsis progression due to bacteremia and inadequate source control.

   Assessment and Plan
   79M w/ hx of critical AS (valve area 0.5cm2), sCHF (EF 40), alcoholic
   cirrhosis, DM, recently admitted w/ sCHF exacerbation and worsening of
   AS, who no p/w persistent severe DOE due to critical AS now awaiting
   valvuloplasty, course complicated by sepsis.
   # Sepsis: Bacteria identified as MSSA. Surveillance x 1negative.. No
   peripheral manifestations of endocarditis, and TTE negative for
   vegetations. No obvious sources for staph bacteremia. Sensitivities
   pending. C diff negative x1.
   - D/c Vanco and Start Nafcillin.
   - Wean phenylephrine as tolerated now that past septic shock and will
   help reduce afterload in setting of critical as
   - Repeat surveillance cx today
   # Critical AS: AS critical by valve area. Plan to undergo valvuloplasty
   today. CXR looks improved today in regards to cephalization. .
   -  Continue phenylephrine for MAPs greater than 55
   -  daily CXR to assess volume status
   -  Valvuloplasty today
   # New onset A fib: Noted on admission. Cardioversion [**6-3**]. Chads 2 is
   4. Was on heparin gtt on the floor but will d/c now given hct drop..
   Not on anticoagulation  while awaiting procedure. Has been in NSR last
   24 hrs.
   - Continue Dofetelide at reduced dose
   - Plan to hold anticoagulation for procedure today (see above). Will
   readress anticoagulation post-procedure.
   # Hyponatremia: Given exam, likely hypovolemic hyponatremia from being
   NPO. Will give fluid gently as needed (see below)
   # Acute renal failure: Cr improved to 1.3 today from 1.8. Likely
   improving with better hemodynamics in the setting of resolving septic
   shock.. Fena 0.2.
   - Trend Cr. Renally dose meds
   - goal 500 cc + today
   # Cirrhosis/G positive stools: - Likely [**2-29**] EtOH use. Pt reports that
   he stopped drinking approx 1 year ago.documented on MRCP as well as CT
   abdomen. Pt hepatitis panel negative for Hep A,B,C. Hct stable since
   admission to CCU.
   -2 pivs
   -active T and S
   -continue PPI
   # ?Aspiration: [**Name8 (MD) **] RN and patient report, patient coughs with thin
   liquids. Will defer swallow eval while NPO.
   - S and S consult tomorrow once NPO order reversed
   # Anxiety/Pain: Will attempt low dose benzo post procedure once stroke
   risk assessed
   # DM
 ISS
   # FEN
 NPO while awaiting
   # Access: Right Cordis with IJ. Was placed while bacteremic so will
   need to be replaced.
   # PPx
 No heparin given ? GIB.
